content.description: Climb right under a roof then go up/left following bolts.
content.location: Starts on a ledge below Lichen it and mossy ledges. A single 70m rope will just barely get you from the tree on top of the cliff to the base of this climb.

content.description: This is the easiest bolted route. It's a fun 5.7 bolt line. See photo
content.location: Get yourself to the top of the Eyes of the World and rappel down. Lichen is the furthest south, (climber's right). There is an anchor at the bottom.

content.description: Climb past the roof on Pippin and keep going right, then follow up a second line of bolts.
content.location: Starts on a ledge below Lichen it and mossy ledges. A single 70m rope will just barely get you from the tree on top of the cliff to the base of this climb.

content.description: Bolted climb. Rap down to the anchor next to the tree jutting out of the cliff. Start there. The crux is one bolt below the anchors. Three finish options are possible. One can stop at the anchors to the right of the bolt line 3/4 of the way up the cliff, this is the original route, it is a good place to set up a top rope, and it is easy to regain the top of the cliff via mossy ledges. The bolts also continue up and veer left, which allows one to continue to the top of the black gate (5.9/5.10 move then easier). Continuing straight up also works, but is a little dirty and run out.
content.location: Rap off the top of the Eyes and find the anchor next to the tree jutting out of the cliff.

content.description: It's a very nice 5.11. There are two cruxes: one near 25 feet and another around 80. This is a mixed route with good cam placements low on the climb and another high on the route. The first crux is near the lower cam protected section while the hardest part of the route is well protected by bolts.
content.location: The bottom anchor is twenty feet left of the tree jutting out of the cliff.

content.description: The Eyes of the World is so named because the view from the top is phenomenal. The trail ends on top of the cliff and you have to rappel down and climb back up. The top of the cliff is about 1,050 feet above sea level and at this writing there isn’t a trail to the bottom of the cliff but there is a brushy trail to the top.  So far local climbers have developed three bolted routes and there is more to develop. It’s the same rock type as the Tee Harbor boulders. Indeed this cliff is a thousand feet above the Tee Harbor boulders and it appears the boulders fell off the cliff some time in the past.  You can hike to the top of the cliff in about 45 minutes. The climb the bolted routes you have to rappel off the cliff and climb back up. There are three anchor points about 25 meters down the wall at the base of each climb. I think a 50 meter rope is too short to reach them if doubled up. There are yet many climbs to be developed.
